"Harakiri" (1962), directed by Masaki Kobayashi, serves as a powerful narrative on the sacred and often misunderstood practice of hara-kiri or seppuku in Japanese culture. This film explores the profound consequences of trivializing such a revered tradition, emphasizing the inevitable repercussions of desecrating what is sacred. The message is clear from the beginning: one must not play with the sanctity of cultural rituals or misuse them for personal gain, for doing so invites the wrath of nature's immutable laws.

The film deftly unravels its plot through a series of natural twists and turns, maintaining a gripping mystery throughout. Although the pacing might seem slow to those not enthralled by the intricacies of suspense and layered storytelling, each revelation adds depth and intensity to the narrative. The meticulous exploration of characters' pasts highlights the complex motives behind the act of hara-kiri, revealing stories steeped in sorrow and despair.

The thin line between honor and life is poignantly depicted, showcasing the extreme measures taken to preserve one's dignity. The film also underscores the importance of empathy, as encapsulated in the profound question, "Who can truly understand the depths of another's heart?" The portrayal of samurai honor as being as politically biased and flawed as modern-day politics adds a critical layer of social commentary.

Ultimately, "Harakiri" is a tragic tale of pride, vengeance, and the hollow nature of superficial honor. It exposes the empty posturing behind claims of dignity, revealing that, in the end, it is often about power and prestige rather than genuine integrity.

Hara-Kiri Directed by Masaki Kobayashi A courageous story about an unemployed samurai fighting for the honor of his son-in-law, daughter and grandson. The way the story unfolds keeps the audience in a constant state of gripping suspense. The story is weaved together from present-time to flashbacks that slowly (making it all the more suspenseful) reveal the true reason as to why Hanshiro wants to commit Hara-Kiri before the Lyi Clan.

In this film, I especially loved the cinematography. As the camera silently glides through the grounds of the Lyi Clan, I felt as though I was a samurai. From the stealth-like camera movement, to the very clean and groomed framing of the actors and the background, to the quiet moments spent waiting for the Hon. Elder to respond to Hanshiro's declaration that, "he is free to choose a second" I felt as though I was a member of the Lyi Clan waiting for Hon. Elder to make his decision.

I think Kobayashi's story of the samurai culture is extremely relatable to many issues we find in today's society. I found many parallels between Kobayashi's depiction of the samurai culture and religious institutions. For my purposes here, I will use Catholicism as an example. However, Catholicism/Christianity is far from the only religion one could find parallels.

In Hara-kiri, the rigid samurai culture adheres to a strict code - the boshido code. However, the way these codes are appropriated leads to abuse of power and corruption. Kobayashi relays this message by focusing on one needle in the haystack - our protagonist Hanshiro. Through his experience, we understand the consequences of these appropriations on a personal level. We see how the samurai culture was full of exclusivity and allowed for their own people to live in poverty and starve to death in exchange for the preservation of their codes. Motome, Hanshiro's son-in-law, was forced to perform Hara-Kiri using a bamboo sword. He pleaded for a few more days before he committed suicide, but they would not listen. The event becomes even more tragic as we discover that the sword was bamboo because he sold the original to save his ailing wife and child.

So how does all of this relate to Catholicism? Similar to the samurai culture's strict principles and ideals, Catholicism has a dogmatic, literal and archaic view point on homosexuality and abortion. The Catholic religion bans gay marriage and refuses to acknowledge, support, or accept homosexual relationships within the church. Recently, NPR did a report about a man who applied for a job in a Catholic school. He met all of the credentials, and they were so pleased with his interview he was hired. However, when he filled out his paperwork, he revealed his husband as a significant other. He was quickly informed he no longer could be employed, because they did not condone gay marriage. And what was the position he applied for, you ask? He applied to be a cook! This story is littered with hypocrisy, judgment, exclusivity, and discrimination. In their determination to preserve these archaic beliefs, they have exemplified hate. Or the fact that Catholic gay couples are having to worship in a separate church. What the church fails to realize is that in order to preserve their doctrine's literal meaning, they are violating the core values that are the foundation of their religion.

In the end of Hara-Kiri, Saito tells a member of the Lyi Clan the story of what will end up in their history books. He does not want his Clan shamed by the incidents that have just happened. Ultimately, despite honesty being the core value of the boshido code and samurai culture, Saito breaks it to preserve the reputation and power of the Lyi Clan.

This is very similar to the current scandals we see today in the Catholic religion. A multitude of sexual molestation cases of young boys by their Catholic priests have occurred. What makes the incidents even worse is the churches knowledge of the scandal and its attempts to cover it up (transferring the priest, bribery,denial). And just like Saito, they too violate one of the core values of their institution - truth.

I went to a museum exhibit in which there were letters encased in glass from young women writing to their local government and religious institutions. They were pleading for a way out. These women were trapped with an unwanted pregnancy and stranded without any options. I remember one woman's tearful letter as she begged for her governor to grant her permission to have an abortion. If her school found out she was pregnant, she would be kicked out of nursing school. She was the first in her family to go to school and her father would disown her if he found out.

Again, another example of how religion has violated their ethical code in order to preserve the sanctity of their institution. Instead of helping these women and looking beyond the text, they left them stranded and forced them to follow through with their unfortunate predicament alone. This is exactly what happened to Motome when he went to the Lyi Clan to plead for money for his dying family.

Beyond even all this, the tale on hand is one of utmost despairing tragedy, the sort that should make any thinking, feeling person blanche in horror, yet on account of the precise, supremely mindful approach taken to the storytelling and film-making, the picture is less likely to evoke the emotions one would assume. Yet none of this is accidental. 'Harakiri' was shaped with only the very highest degree of skill and intelligence, an indefatigable purposefulness that meets or exceeds all points of comparison, and any possible expectations. The patient, thoughtful viewer is rewarded with an exquisite masterpiece that in my opinion meets or exceeds any standard one might carry in mind for cinema. This is without question one of the greatest movies ever made, putting to shame the vast majority of anything that has ever been generously granted such a label.

'Harakiri' is perfect. Every note in the increasingly sparing original score of Takemitsu Toru is deployed with an ingenuity that complements, reinforces, and amplifies the hushed yet spellbinding drama that unfolds. Impeccable sound design makes even soft footfalls inspire as the brilliant, fastidious choices that they are amidst the craftsmanship. Rarely has an editor deserved praise more than Sagara Hisashi, for rarely have I so plainly been able to recognize the finesse and artistry that film editing might boast in the hands of a wizard. Miyajima Yoshio's cinematography is rich, crisp, and vivid, smartly visualizing every detail for us in a manner that both accentuates the drama and bolsters the artistry that overflows in the vision of filmmaker Kobayashi Masaki. To date I can't claim to be familiar enough with Kobayashi to speak directly to any point of comparison, yet in watching this feature I'm pointedly reminded of Kurosawa Akira, a man known for his perfectionism - be it true or not, I detect the same level of painstaking diligence in Kobayashi's work here, and that is only the highest of compliments. All this is to say nothing of those facets that more commonly earn praise, like the gorgeous sets and filming locations, lovely costume design, hair and makeup, and props and weapons, and vibrant choreography, stunts, and effects. Yet incredibly, flawless as these facets are, they just aren't the first to catch one's attention.

Given the overall tenor of this title one could be forgiven for not being immediately swept away by the acting, itself mostly understated and restrained. Like all else here, however, there is stupendous subtlety in the performances that belies the searing drama of the saga and the fervency of the underlying emotions. All involved - not least Iwashita Shima, Mikuni Rentaro, Ishihama Akira, and especially star Nakadai Tatsuya - are to be congratulated for momentously strong portrayals that bring their characters to such stark life in the realization of so gripping a tale. And with all this firmly in mind, it is a tremendous credit to Kobayashi, to producer Hosoya Tatsuo, and to every contributor, above all Hashimoto Shinobu in adapting Takiguchi Yasuhiko's novel, that the story here is so incredibly powerful and impactful. I sat to watch with no foreknowledge save for the film's reputation, and I am altogether stunned. The low-key tack adopted throughout most of these 133 minutes allows the dialogue, scene writing, and narrative to speak entirely for themselves, slowly laying the groundwork and stirring the pot while building to a terrible crescendo quite unlike any other. The premise seems simple as down-and-out ronin Tsugumo approaches the Iyi clan with a request to commit harakiri, and first explains the course of events that led him to this juncture. What unfolds instead, through intermittent cuts to flashback and to the active plot, is a deeply absorbing and compelling story that through to the end only becomes more dour and dispiriting.

Moreover, through the framework of that story, Kobayashi and Hashimoto latch onto bigger ideas and themes that reverberate like a thunderclap and which remain infuriatingly relevant to our modern world. 'Harakiri' is, at its core, a fiery, strident, cleverly devised manifesto. This is nothing if not a vehement condemnation of the adoption of symbols by movements, subcultures, and broader societies, and of the dogmatic codes that zealously cling to those symbols while not just forsaking reason, compassion, and humanity, but also the very values and principles that such symbols and codes are purported to represent and ensure. In some measure I'm reminded of Abel Gance's 1919 epic anti-war classic 'J'accuse': this may specifically target the practices and code of honor of the samurai, but Kobayashi's ferocious statement applies just as equally to any society that puts some emblem on a pedestal - a flag, a ribbon, an ideal - and whether in word or on paper enshrines a system (codes, laws) that emptily prioritizes such emblems and uses it as a shield, a thin veil, to mask horrid, harmful, iniquitous behavior. That the picture does all this while also demonstrating expert craftsmanship, telling a riveting story, and embracing magnificent artistry, can only mean that the end result is a treasure with precious, precious few works that can call it kin.

This has been on my list to watch for a long time, and I anticipated enjoying it, but I am completely taken aback by what has actually greeted me. I'm aghast that it's taken me so long to see it; I'm almost heartbroken and offended that it's not widely held in much higher regard, and more routinely recognized. As far as I'm concerned the sum total is in every way a piece of cinema beyond all reproach, with fantastically shrewd notions at every turn. Even the climax and the ending defy our assumptions: we get action violence, but tactfully dispensed and cut such that it is as artistic as it is exciting; Tsugumo is a virtuous protagonist, and a fierce warrior, but he is not a "one-man army" who will tirelessly cut down all his foes; there is a patient deliberateness in the climax that flies in the face of the hard-charging bombast that characterizes much modern fare; the flick concludes with a denouement that bucks the norms and standards of much of cinema, further cementing the central themes while resolving the plot in a fashion that is at once both satisfying and upsetting. What here is less than superlative? In my estimation the answer is "nothing." For various reasons this may not readily appeal to all comers, and strictly speaking we all have different personal preferences where movies are concerned. Be that as it may, there is no doubt in my mind that this is one of the very best features in all of cinema, and it would be an awful mistake to pass up an opportunity to watch. 'Harakiri' is a truly essential classic that's well worth seeking out however one must, and I'm happy to give it my very, very highest, heartiest, most enthusiastic recommendation!

review_title: Watch this Fascinating and Moving Story Unfold

Beautifully shot in black and white and masterfully showing Japanese restraint in its pacing, the film examines the Samurai Bushido (honor) code. But, as a proud ronin named Hanshiro recounts (often through flashbacks) his moving personal story to the Samurai of the House of Iyi, the story unfolds in unexpected ways and we get an opportunity to stare into the souls of those proud Samurai. We also get the opportunity to asses where true honor lies. Is it honorable to adhere to the expected rules and rituals, or is it more honorable to reassess the rules as times of change and to let go of rigidity to show compassion to fellow humans in need?

review_title: A Quick Look Into Dogmatic Interpretation of the Bushido Code
Strikingly shot, tense engaging build-up, weighty ending
review_detailed_main:
Harakiri is the fourth classic-Japanese film I've seen, after Samurai 1 Musashi, Rashomon, Seven Samurai. It is comfortably my favourite as unlike the others it hasn't noticably dated nor has any clear flaws.

The glacial pace doesn't drag as we're treated to a near-constant stream of visually-striking compositions, a photographer's film! The black-n-white is quite beautiful, with just the right amount of contrast (I recommend the Bluray, for optimal dynamic range).

What the camera does is one thing, a good film still needs a compelling narrative, and we get that too. The first half-hour is a little confusing, but once the story finds its groove (or rather, once the viewer has 'tuned in') then it's quite gripping. We want to know what Tsugumo's game is...

The most impressive accomplishment of the narrative is how it puts its main message across, regarding bushido. I won't explicitly state that message here, as first-time viewers should experience it within the film. It's an impressive ending.

The cast are all decent, music totally sparse yet effective. Subtitles were fine, clear & concise. The action is mostly quite good (for an early-60's flick) tho' there was one sword-swipe which clearly missed its mark despite the victim falling prey to it. Forgiveable, given the age of the film...and understandable, given the actors used real swords! The sets and setting feel authentic, tho' lacking a little in variety. While the slow pacing and precise dialogue isn't an issue, it does make Harakiri a 'watch-when-in-the-mood' type film...not one to put on at any time.

Overall a strong 8/10. The first classic-japanese to get that score. I already enjoy anime & horror from Japan-cinema (Akira, Grave of the Fireflies & The Grudge are probably my top 3 japanese films)...I wasn't sure if the 50's/60's stuff was for me. Now with Harakiri I'm beginning to see the appeal. On account of this strong showing the next film of this ilk will be from the same director: either Kwaidan or deep dive into his Human Condition trilogy.

Harakiri is a masterfully constructed period drama by director Masaki Kobayashi. The film is expertly set up and provides the viewer with a thought provoking, entertaining two hours of both brilliant dialogue and suspenseful action.

The film starts with the protagonist of the story, Tsugumo Hanshiro (Tatsuya Nakadai), as an out of work Samurai requesting to commit Harakiri (Seppuku) because he feels he wants to end his life honorably instead of poor and hungry. The counselor of the clan tells Hanshiro a story similar to what is happening now and the other samurai's grisly fate to deter him, but Hanshiro remains committed to his cause.

The film is told through a series of stories, using flashbacks and narration to move the story along. Kobayashi effectively used the flashbacks and allows the viewer to easily follow the story line while jumping between different stories and timelines.

While the acting of Hanshiro and the Counselor is of a higher tier than most, some of the supporting actors fall flat and leave much to be desired. For example, in the film, when Hanshiro is telling a story of his daughter and her husband, the characters end up being a little flat and not living up to their full potential. Their acting wasn't pivotal in the advancement of the story so it didn't deter the viewer's enjoyment of the film.

Overall this film was deep and the viewer realized that both the protagonist and antagonist both have their own motivations. I found myself thinking about this film and the messages it conveyed long after I finished watching it. There are parallels that can be drawn with current events and even could cause you to reassess your own moral code. I highly recommend this well-written film.

Similarities between Kobayashi's Harakiri and films of the French new wave arose to me under the comical disobedience of authority. While the authority being questioned in movies such as Godard's "Breathless" is mostly directed towards the rules of filming present at the time, the authority being dismissed here is obviously the one behind the Bushido code, held by Saito. The combat scenes seem authentic in a way that is almost comical--ignoring what they may look like ideally, the director is able to make us feel the adrenalin present within Hanshiro during the fight scenes. This comical use of real actions, along with the demystification of the Iyi clan leader, helps expose the viewer to the idealized values present during the Tokugawa era, which although questionable, have been believed by many.

"Seppuku" is the movie which makes you think where you are at in the society. And makes you to look back to remind what you have been missing for your own "Bushido code".
